items.title: MSU dairy scientist says unknown risks are too great for raw milk to be allowed
items.description: A long-time dairy quality specialist says the unpredictable risks of drinking raw milk are too great to legalize its sale. Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine‚Äôs Dr. Pamela Ruegg tells Brownfield, ‚ÄúIt’s a documented risk.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe challenge with that risk is that the risk and the vulnerabilities of people is not equally distributed,‚Äù she […] The post MSU dairy scientist says unknown risks are too great for raw milk to be allowed appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine's Dr. Pamela Ruegg, a long-time dairy quality specialist, believes the unpredictable risks of drinking raw milk are too great to legalize its sale. She states that the risk and vulnerabilities of people are not equally distributed, making raw milk consumption a documented risk. Dr. Ruegg emphasizes that the unknown risks associated with raw milk are too significant to allow its legalization.

items.title: Playing the Trump card with India
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Markets continue to move (this time positively) on trade talk headlines.
items.summary:
The agricultural markets are being heavily influenced by the ongoing trade negotiations between the U.S. and India. On Wednesday, President Trump threatened to impose retaliatory tariffs on India, a top trading partner, in response to the country's high tariffs on U.S. agricultural products. Trump stated that India has "long been tariff king" and the U.S. has been "charging nothing" in comparison. This comes as the two countries attempt to finalize a trade deal, with the U.S. seeking greater market access for its farm goods in India. 

India currently imposes tariffs as high as 100% on some U.S. agricultural imports, such as almonds, walnuts, and apples. In 2018, U.S. agricultural exports to India were valued at $1.2 billion. If trade tensions escalate, it could significantly impact U.S. farmers who rely on the Indian market. Industry experts recommend that U.S. farmers continue to closely monitor the trade talks and be prepared to adjust their marketing strategies accordingly.

items.title: Sustainable and Stylish: Trends in Rural Home Design for 2026
items.description: Philadelphia, Pa. — The perfect picture of rural life has been changed radically. Automation in 2026 does not imply the loss of luxury or aesthetics to go off the grid, or to move to the country. The modern country home, in its turn, is a symbol of efficiency, and it has the features of high […] The post Sustainable and Stylish: Trends in Rural Home Design for 2026 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Sustainable living has increased creativity in rural home design, moving away from the "farmhouse chic" of past decades.
- The modern country home in 2026 is a symbol of efficiency and features high-tech sustainability as well as refined, luxury interiors.
- Key design elements include:
  - Use of natural light and passive solar design
  - Living walls and vertical gardens in main living areas
  - Earth-toned color palettes instead of stark whites and grays
  - Eco-conscious materials like cross-laminated timber and circular furniture
- "Invisible" smart home technology is being integrated for water autonomy, climate control, and energy independence (e.g. solar shingles).
- The "slow living" aesthetic is emphasized, with homeowners working with local craftspeople on unique, handmade furnishings and decor.
- Three key design profiles are identified: The Modern Monolith, The Soft Sanctuary, and The Industrial Barn.
- The 2026 rural home aims to balance sustainability and beauty, without having to choose between the two.

items.title: New year brings heightened ag economic concerns
items.description: Ag Economy Barometer shows sharp drop in farmer sentiment to start 2026 amid growing pessimism about exports and future outlook.
items.summary:
The Ag Economy Barometer, a monthly survey of 400 U.S. agricultural producers, showed a sharp 15% drop in farmer sentiment in January 2026 compared to the previous month. The index fell from 141 in December 2025 to 120 in January 2026, indicating heightened economic concerns among farmers. 

A key factor driving the decline was growing pessimism about agricultural exports, with 58% of surveyed farmers expecting exports to decrease over the next 12 months, up from 37% in December. Farmers also expressed more uncertainty about their farm's financial performance, with just 44% expecting better financial performance in the year ahead, down from 58% the prior month.

Concerns over government policies and rising production costs were also cited as major contributors to the drop in farmer sentiment. The White House's recently announced $20 billion aid package for the agricultural sector provided some optimism, but farmers remained uncertain about its long-term impact.

Economists warn that the decline in farmer sentiment could translate to reduced investment and spending on farms, potentially slowing economic growth in rural America. They advise farmers to closely monitor market conditions and government policy changes in the months ahead.

items.title: Ag Committee Chairs Honored for Seeking Bipartisan Solutions
items.description: MANKATO, Minn. — For over 60 years, the Minnesota Soybean Growers Association (MSGA) has been steadfast in promoting sensible, farm-related policies that can garner support from all sides of the political spectrum. In 2024, the farmer-led organization created the Spirit of MSGA Award to recognize legislative leaders who reach across the aisle, even if it‚Äôs […] The post Ag Committee Chairs Honored for Seeking Bipartisan Solutions appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
In 2026, MSGA honored Republican Representative Paul Anderson and Democratic Senator Aric Putnam with the award.

Key details:
- MSGA represents nearly 26,000 soybean farmers in Minnesota
- The award recognizes leaders who reach across the aisle, even if it's not politically popular, to support legislation that benefits agriculture
- Rep. Anderson has served in the Minnesota House since 2009 and currently chairs the House Agriculture Committee
- Sen. Putnam has chaired the Senate Agriculture Committee since 2022 and has worked with Rep. Anderson to pass MSGA priority policies
- Policies supported include funding agriculture programs, international marketing, rural infrastructure, beginning farmer support, animal agriculture protection, rural mental health, and establishing a grain indemnity fund
- With a split government, bipartisan cooperation was required to pass an agricultural omnibus bill

Quotes:
- "We feel it's important in this moment to honor those policy leaders who are demonstrating a willingness to go beyond politics to support common-sense policies that move agriculture forward." - MSGA President Darin Johnson
- "Minnesota is poised to really lead the way to increase biofuels, which is going to be key to getting our margins back up." - Rep. Paul Anderson
- "What we're supposed to do (as politicians) is come up with something that's not partisan at all ‚Ä¶ and to talk to people and learn who are impacted by the decisions we make." - Sen. Aric Putnam

The article notes that MSGA looks forward to continued engagement with Rep. Anderson, Sen. Putnam, and the Walz administration during the 2026 Legislative Session.

items.title: UMN Extension to Offer Hands On Apple Pruning Workshops
items.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — University of Minnesota Extension is offering a series of apple tree pruning workshops across the state. These workshops will take place throughout February, March and April, the time of year when apple trees are dormant and pruning is recommended. The workshops will provide guidance on proper pruning methods and focus on […] The post UMN Extension to Offer Hands On Apple Pruning Workshops appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
University of Minnesota Extension is offering a series of apple tree pruning workshops across the state in February, March, and April 2026. These workshops will provide guidance on proper pruning methods and focus on hands-on practice pruning trees at apple orchards.

The workshops will be held on the following dates and locations:
- Van Lin Orchard, Monday, February 9, 2026 in La Crescent, MN
- Apple Creek Orchard, Thursday, March 5, 2026 in Faribault, MN
- Cook County Community Center, Friday, March 13, 2026 in Grand Marais, MN
- Peter's Pumpkins and Carmen's Corn, Thursday, March 19, 2026 in Shakopee, MN
- Red Barn Greenhouse, Monday, March 23, 2026 in New York Mills, MN
- Clay County Extension, Thursday, April 23, 2026 in Moorhead, MN

The workshops will be led by local Extension Educators and Madeline Wimmer, Extension Educator, Fruit Production. The cost of all workshops is $20, with some locations offering alternative pricing models.

Proper pruning of apple trees is important to optimize fruit growth and ease of harvest. These workshops will be useful for homeowners, gardeners, Master Gardener volunteers, and orchardists of all experience levels throughout Minnesota.

Pre-registration is required as each workshop will be at location capacity. Payment can be made online at the time of registration, or by check at the door. In case of inclement weather, cancellation or confirmation of each workshop will be communicated to registered participants.

items.title: Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit to Educate Community on Local Water Quality
items.description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis. — The UW‚ÄìMadison Division of Extension is hosting the Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit, a one-day educational event designed to increase water quality awareness by providing local information that enables community members to make informed decisions. The summit will be held on Friday, March 20, 2026, from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., […] The post Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit to Educate Community on Local Water Quality appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The UW-Madison Division of Extension is hosting the Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit on Friday, March 20, 2026, from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. The event will take place at Chippewa Valley Technical College's West Campus in Eau Claire, Wisconsin. 

The summit is designed to increase water quality awareness by providing local information to enable community members, including homeowners, landowners, farmers, agency staff, and industries, to make informed decisions. Sessions will cover topics like PFAS, soil and water interactions, local water testing and services, and conserving soil, water, and nutrients. 

The cost to attend is $20, and advance registration is required by March 9th. For more information or to register, visit the provided link.

items.title: Manure vs. synthetic fertilizer: nutrient balance key for corn growers, expert says
items.description: Comparing the value of manure to synthetic fertilizers in corn production can be complicated. University of Minnesota Extension specialist Melissa Wilson tells Brownfield farmers looking to manure as a cheaper alternative should consider which nutrients are most necessary. “If you’re already high (in) phosphorous and potassium levels, then you’re not going to get as big […] The post Manure vs. synthetic fertilizer: nutrient balance key for corn growers, expert says appear
items.summary: University of Minnesota Extension specialist Melissa Wilson advises that farmers considering using manure as a cheaper alternative should evaluate their nutrient levels. If phosphorus and potassium levels are already high, the benefits of using manure may be limited. Wilson states that the key is to maintain the right nutrient balance for corn crops. Farmers need to assess their specific nutrient needs and soil conditions to determine the optimal fertilizer approach, whether manure, synthetic fertilizers, or a combination. The article highlights the importance of understanding the nutrient profile and potential impacts on crop yields when making decisions between manure and synthetic fertilizers.

items.title: Prepare For Spring And Summer Storms With Flood Insurance
items.description: MADISON, Wis. ‚Äì The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources (DNR) encourages Wisconsinites to learn about flood risks across the state and available flood insurance options during Flood Insurance Awareness Week, Feb. 1-7, 2026. According to the Wisconsin Initiative on Climate Change Impacts’ 2021 Assessment Report, the past decade was the wettest on record. Because flooding has historically […] The post Prepare For Spring And Summer Storms With Flood Insurance appeared first on Mor
items.summary:
According to the Wisconsin Initiative on Climate Change Impacts, the past decade was the wettest on record in the state, and flooding has historically been Wisconsin's most common natural hazard.

Homeowner and renter insurance policies typically do not cover flood damage, so a separate flood insurance policy is required. Federal flood insurance is available for properties both inside and outside designated Special Flood Hazard Areas, but is only offered to residents of communities that participate in the National Flood Insurance Program. Nationally, 40% of National Flood Insurance Program claims come from outside of federally designated flood zones, and 98% of claims from the 2025 southeastern Wisconsin storm were from outside flood zones.

The DNR's Floodplain Program oversees community enrollment in the National Flood Insurance Program and provides expertise. Most National Flood Insurance Program policies have a standard 30-day waiting period before coverage begins. Property owners in Special Flood Hazard Areas with federally regulated mortgages are required to carry flood insurance.

Insurance Commissioner Nathan Houdek noted that just 1 inch of water can cause up to $25,000 in damage, underscoring the importance of flood insurance for renters, homeowners, and business owners. Additional flood insurance and risk mitigation resources are available from the Wisconsin Office of the Commissioner of Insurance.

items.title: Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers
items.description: The president of the Kansas Soybean Association says delays over the Renewable Fuel Standard are testing the patience of the ag industry. Brett Neibling says the lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations is frustrating. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs hard. Every time I have a conversation with someone it feels like we‚Äôre still […] The post Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The president of the Kansas Soybean Association, Brett Neibling, says delays in finalizing the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) are frustrating farmers. The lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations (RVOs) is causing uncertainty in the agriculture industry. Neibling expressed his exasperation, stating, "Every time I have a conversation with someone it feels like we're still waiting on the RVOs." The delays in the RFS are testing the patience of farmers who rely on this policy to support the biofuels market and provide a consistent demand for their crops.

items.title: Wintery weather bringing basis opportunities
items.description: Challenging winter weather is bringing marketing opportunities to some farmers. Doug Crop, grain merchandiser with Premier Cooperative in east central Illinois, says the recent stretch of winter storms and bitter cold has caused transportation challenges. ‚ÄúWith the river system, with this cold weather and barges being locked in with the ice, even on the rail […] The post Wintery weather bringing basis opportunities appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The recent stretch of winter storms and bitter cold in east central Illinois has caused transportation challenges, creating marketing opportunities for some farmers. Doug Crop, a grain merchandiser with Premier Cooperative, says the cold weather and ice have disrupted barge and rail transportation. This has led to wider basis levels, meaning farmers can potentially get better prices for their grain. Crop advises farmers to monitor the market closely and consider their options to capitalize on the basis opportunities arising from the wintery weather.

items.title: Kuhn introduces new livestock and crop products
items.description: SLC 200 manure spreaders, RC 300 mixers, 9600 grain drills and Advance .1 fertilizer spreaders now available in North America.
items.summary:
Kuhn, a major agricultural equipment manufacturer, has introduced several new products for livestock and crop production in North America. 

The new products include:
- SLC 200 manure spreaders
- RC 300 mixers
- 9600 grain drills
- Advance .1 fertilizer spreaders

These products are now available for purchase by farmers in the North American market.

The SLC 200 manure spreaders have a capacity of 200 cubic feet and are designed for efficient and uniform manure application. The RC 300 mixers can handle a volume of 300 cubic feet for mixing feed, bedding, or other materials. The 9600 grain drills offer 16-foot working widths for planting crops, while the Advance .1 fertilizer spreaders can spread granular fertilizers with an application rate up to 43 pounds per acre.

These new product introductions by Kuhn aim to provide farmers with advanced equipment options to improve productivity and efficiency in their livestock and crop operations.

items.title: Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026
items.description: The president-elect of the Ohio Pork Council is outlining the organization’s top policy concerns for 2026. Jarred Black says the industry continues to face ag labor challenges. “We have generational changes and staffing shortages across the area and the state,” he says. “We need to be able to have a good access pool of on-farm […] The post Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026 appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The Ohio Pork Council is focused on addressing agricultural labor shortages and the impact of Proposition 12 in 2026. 

Jarred Black, the president-elect of the Ohio Pork Council, stated that the industry is facing "generational changes and staffing shortages" across the state. The council aims to ensure a good pool of on-farm labor to support the pork industry.

Additionally, the council is working to find a solution to the challenges posed by Proposition 12, a California law that sets new minimum space requirements for certain farm animals, including pigs. The council plans to address this issue in 2026.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: The agricultural giant is reshaping sales leadership to seize market advantages and fuel what‚Äôs next. Get to know Chris Reynolds in this CropLife exclusive. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a major agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Reynolds aims to leverage Nutrien's scale and diverse product portfolio to better serve farmers and capitalize on emerging market trends.

Key points:
- Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with over $23 billion in annual sales.
- As Global Sales Lead, Reynolds will oversee Nutrien's sales strategy and execution across 14 countries.
- Reynolds plans to enhance Nutrien's digital capabilities, improve customer experience, and expand the company's sustainability offerings.
- He emphasizes the importance of listening to farmers' needs and tailoring Nutrien's solutions to help them increase productivity and profitability.
- Reynolds believes Nutrien's size and scope give it a unique advantage to support farmers in a rapidly changing agricultural landscape.

The article does not provide specific timelines or deadlines. However, the changes under Reynolds' leadership are expected to position Nutrien for continued growth and better serve farmers' evolving needs.

items.title: Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy
items.description: Adjuvants gain importance as EPA‚Äôs Herbicide Strategy elevates them from optional add-ons to essential tools reducing drift. The post Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The EPA's new Herbicide Strategy has elevated the importance of adjuvants for farmers. Adjuvants, which were previously considered optional add-ons, are now essential tools for reducing pesticide drift. This shift is driven by the EPA's focus on minimizing the environmental impact of herbicides. Farmers must now carefully select adjuvants that are approved for use with specific herbicides to ensure compliance with the EPA's regulations. The use of approved adjuvants can help farmers avoid fines or other penalties for non-compliance. Industry experts emphasize the need for farmers to closely follow label instructions and work closely with their chemical suppliers to identify the most effective and compliant adjuvant solutions for their operations.

items.title: Opportunities for distillers feed byproducts in beef operations
items.description: Distillers provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein that can fit in many cow, backgrounding and finishing systems.
items.summary:
Distillers feed byproducts offer valuable opportunities for beef operations. Distillers provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein, with dried distillers grains with solubles (DDGS) containing 30% crude protein and 12% fat. 

Research shows DDGS can make up 40-50% of a beef finishing diet with no negative impacts on performance or carcass quality. In backgrounding programs, DDGS can replace up to 75% of the forage. Feeding DDGS has been shown to increase average daily gain by 0.25-0.50 lbs per day in finishing cattle compared to corn-based diets.

Wet distillers grains with solubles (WDGS) are another option, typically costing $20-30 per ton less than DDGS. WDGS can be included up to 50% of the diet for finishing cattle. Feeding WDGS increased hot carcass weight by 24 lbs compared to a corn-based diet.

Dr. Galen Erickson, beef cattle nutritionist at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, states that distillers products are an excellent feed ingredient for beef producers looking to improve profitability and performance.

items.title: Ever.Ag launches Feedlot IQ
items.description: AI-powered platform designed to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health and make more informed decisions.
items.summary:
Ever.Ag has launched Feedlot IQ, an AI-powered platform to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health, and make more informed decisions. Feedlot IQ leverages computer vision and machine learning to monitor cattle behavior and performance in real-time.

The platform can track metrics like feed consumption, resting time, and drinking patterns, and provide alerts for potential health issues. This allows feedyards to make proactive interventions to maintain cattle health and productivity.

Feedlot IQ integrates with existing systems and can be deployed across multiple pens and camera networks. It provides a centralized dashboard for feedyard managers to view analytics and insights.

According to Kevin Penner, President of Feedlot Solutions at Ever.Ag, "Feedlot IQ gives feedyards the tools they need to optimize their operations and make more informed, data-driven decisions to support animal welfare and improve profitability."

The launch of Feedlot IQ comes as feedyards face challenges like labor shortages, rising input costs, and the need to demonstrate robust animal care practices. Feedlot IQ aims to help address these issues by providing real-time visibility and data-driven decision support.

items.title: America’s farmers are cornerstones of Super Bowl parties
items.description: A new analysis shows how popular game-day foods depend on a vast farm and ranch supply chain, even as producers face mounting financial strain. The post America’s farmers are cornerstones of Super Bowl parties appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
S., behind only Thanksgiving. This event highlights the strength and reach of U.S. agriculture, as well as the challenges facing American farmers and ranchers.

Key statistics:
- Corn tortilla chips are the most consumed snack, with over 90 million acres of corn planted annually. However, corn farmers are projected to lose an average of $173 per acre in 2026.
- Potato chips are the second most popular snack. Potato farmers faced an estimated $700 million in losses in 2025 due to rising costs.
- Americans are expected to eat over 1 billion chicken wings, supplied by poultry farmers who operate in a highly consolidated, contract-based system. Poultry growers often invest $1 million or more in specialized buildings and equipment.
- Dairy products like cheese are used extensively, but the U.S. has seen a 60% decline in dairy farms since 2005, down to 24,800 operations as of 2024.

The article notes the economic pressures facing farmers, including low crop prices, rising costs, and a consolidated production system. AFBF President Zippy Duvall states that while farmers are proud to grow the food for Super Bowl parties, they are facing an economic crisis and need further assistance to stay in business.

items.title: Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization
items.description: The appointment follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. The post Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Chris Reynolds has been appointed to lead Nutrien's global sales organization, following a planned leadership transition. Jeff Tarsi is stepping into an advisory role. Reynolds has over 25 years of experience in the agriculture industry, including roles at Bayer and Monsanto. As the new President of Global Sales, he will oversee Nutrien's sales and distribution efforts worldwide. Nutrien is one of the world's largest providers of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries. The company reported $27.7 billion in net sales in 2021. Reynolds' appointment aims to strengthen Nutrien's global reach and support farmers with the products and services they need.

items.title: PLC and BLM team up to strengthen grazing monitoring on public lands
items.description: The Public Lands Council and the Bureau of Land Management signed a 2026‚ÄìJanuary 2031 memorandum of understanding to improve rangeland management. The post PLC and BLM team up to strengthen grazing monitoring on public lands appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Public Lands Council (PLC) and the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to promote cooperative monitoring of grazing allotments on BLM lands. The MOU will last from 2026 to January 2031 and aims to strengthen the partnership between federal agencies and public lands ranchers.

The goals of the MOU are to:
- Improve data collection and information sharing between grazing permittees and BLM
- Utilize ranchers' on-the-ground knowledge and stewardship to inform land management decisions
- Ensure decisions are based on sound data and collaborative monitoring
- Achieve resilient landscapes that support productive grazing, healthy wildlife habitat, and clean water

The data collected by permittees through approved methods will provide BLM with more reference points when evaluating rangeland health and resource management. This will also create clear records of the positive results from ranchers' investments in resilient rangelands.

PLC's Tim Canterbury stated that the MOU will "allow BLM and grazing permittees to better share the information that is key to those management efforts." BLM's Acting Director Bill Groffy added that public lands ranchers are "essential partners in sustaining healthy rangelands" and this MOU will strengthen the agencies' ability to work side-by-side with permittees.

The MOU builds on a similar agreement PLC signed with the Forest Service in 2022, demonstrating an ongoing commitment to cooperative monitoring on public lands.

items.title: Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control
items.description: Experts to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment. The post Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Weed Science Society of America (WSSA) will host a symposium on December 6-7, 2022 to explore the future of targeted and autonomous weed control technologies. Experts from academia, industry, and government will discuss the opportunities and challenges in developing sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment.

Key topics to be covered include advancements in computer vision, artificial intelligence, and robotics, as well as economic and regulatory considerations for adopting these technologies. Participants will also explore the potential for integrating these precision tools with traditional weed management strategies to improve outcomes for farmers.

The symposium aims to bridge the gap between research and real-world application, providing a platform for collaboration and knowledge sharing. Attendees will include representatives from major agribusiness companies, equipment manufacturers, and university researchers.

items.title: Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase
items.description: January Ag Economy Barometer plunges as farmers report worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns, according to Purdue University. The post Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Ag Economy Barometer, a monthly survey of farmer sentiment conducted by Purdue University, saw a sharp drop in January 2026. The index plunged to 102, down 19 points from December 2025. This sharp decline reflects increasing economic concerns among farmers, including worsening farm finances, rising debt, and worries about agricultural exports.

The Index of Current Conditions fell 18 points to 99, while the Index of Future Expectations dropped 20 points to 103. Nearly half (49%) of farmers reported weaker farm finances compared to a year earlier, up from 41% in December. The percentage of farmers with a positive outlook on their farm's financial situation in the next 12 months dropped from 34% in December to just 27% in January.

Farmers also expressed greater concerns about rising debt levels, with 39% reporting higher farm debt compared to a year ago, up from 33% the prior month. Additionally, 38% of farmers said they expect decreasing agricultural exports over the next 5 years, a significant increase from 28% in December.

The results highlight the growing economic challenges faced by the agricultural sector, with farmers reporting worsening finances, rising debt burdens, and concerns about export markets. This decline in farmer sentiment may prompt calls for increased government support and policy interventions to assist the struggling farm economy.

items.title: Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made
items.description: Sugar is a common part of Americans' nutritional intake. Here's how sugar is created, starting with how it's produced on farms. The post Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Main news/finding: This article explains the process of how sugar is grown and made, from sugar beets and sugar cane to the final refined sugar product.

Key numbers/statistics:
- About 60% of sugar in the U.S. comes from sugar beets.
- Sugar beets typically weigh between 3-5 pounds each.
- Sugar cane can grow up to 10-20 feet tall.

Dates/deadlines: None mentioned.

People/organizations/programs: Michelle Miller (the Farm Babe), TerraForma.

Locations: Minnesota, Idaho, North Dakota, Michigan, Nebraska, Florida, Louisiana.

Context/causes: Sugar is a common ingredient in many foods and drinks, but the process of how it is produced is not widely known.

Impacts for farmers: Sugar beets and sugar cane are important crops for farmers in the mentioned states. The by-products from sugar processing, like molasses and beet pulp, also have value as animal feed.

Recommendations/action items: None.

Expert quotes: None.

In summary, this article provides a comprehensive overview of how sugar is grown and manufactured, from the sugar beet and sugar cane crops to the final refined sugar product. It explains the key steps in the production process, the geographic regions where these crops are grown, and the various by-products that are created during sugar processing.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
The system captures water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, stores it in a pond, and then reuses it as supplemental irrigation during droughts. The Blairs' system was part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship.

Building the pond was a bigger conservation project than the Blairs had done before. While recent rains have prevented them from fully calculating the yield benefits, data from Iowa State shows there are yield increases. The system is used primarily later in the growing season when Iowa often experiences drought. 

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found that drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually and save $10-$20 per acre in operating costs. It can also provide water quality benefits by reducing nutrient runoff.

The upfront costs for a system like this are $2-$3 million, plus maintenance. Experts recommend having a pond capable of storing 4-6 inches of water for the irrigated area. Financing often requires both private investment from the farmer and public/outside funding.

Drainage water recycling is not a common practice but is gaining interest due to water quality concerns. The Environmental Defense Fund is working to inform stakeholders and explore funding approaches to make the practice more feasible. Farmer Kellie Blair advises seeking local help when setting up a system.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate:

- Bayer is hopeful the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in the case of Monsanto Company v. Durnell, where it will argue glyphosate labels approved by the EPA do not require a cancer warning.

- Bayer has publicly acknowledged spending over $12 billion on lawsuits over glyphosate. The company has a 15-11 record in court, with 9 consecutive wins when the court allows them to present the scientific evidence that glyphosate does not cause cancer.

- The Supreme Court case could go either way, but if Bayer wins, it could quell the tide of lawsuits. Thousands of claims, mostly from residential users, are still in the system.

- Bayer continues to engage with policymakers, manage current cases, develop new formulations, and maintain a safety study webpage on glyphosate.

- However, Gough acknowledged there may come a time when Bayer has to question the viability of continuing the glyphosate business due to the litigation.

- The American Sugarbeet Growers Association is working on an amicus brief for the Supreme Court case, as the development of Roundup Ready sugarbeets was a big step for weed control.

- Gough said the constant litigation over glyphosate provides a template for trial lawyers to go after other pesticides, making companies less likely to invest in new chemistries.

items.title: Starter Flock Program helps students get involved in the Targhee sheep breed
items.description: In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota, received her starter flock through the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. Now her breeding program continues to grow.
items.summary:
S. Targhee Sheep Association. The program aims to help young people get involved in the Targhee sheep breed by providing them with a starter flock.

The Starter Flock Program awards recipients with three ewes, with at least one of those being a ewe lamb donated by members of the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. This helps reduce the financial barrier for young people to get started in the livestock industry.

Annabel has continued to grow her Targhee sheep flock since receiving the starter flock in 2023. The Targhee breed is known for its wool and meat production.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any dates, deadlines, or expert quotes.

The key organizations involved are the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association, which runs the Starter Flock Program, and Annabel Coudron, the recipient of the starter flock in Marshall, Minnesota.

The program aims to make it more accessible for young people to get involved in the Targhee sheep breed, which can be challenging otherwise. By providing the starter flock, it reduces the initial financial investment required.

Overall, the article highlights how the Starter Flock Program is helping to get more young people involved in raising Targhee sheep through the support of a starter flock.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: In 2024, City Green, a program within this network, produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds. This is significant as conflict in the Middle East has devastated Palestinian farmland and food systems. These seeds are now a symbol of hope for many Palestinians. The network of US farmers is working to expand the distribution of these seeds to Palestinian communities to support the preservation of traditional Palestinian crops and farming practices.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key points:

- The USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon along the Texas-Mexico border to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm (NWS).

- The dispersal facility at Moore Air Base in Texas is expected to be fully operational within 2-3 weeks after initial testing.

- The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (TSCRA) commends the progress and collaboration with USDA, but recommends keeping the U.S.-Mexico border closed to livestock imports until the threat of NWS can be minimized.

- Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and USDA will keep the border closed based on science and preparedness, not pressure.

- A single incursion of NWS into Texas or the U.S. could have devastating economic consequences for livestock producers, wildlife, and landowners.

- TSCRA, a 148-year-old trade association with over 28,000 members, stands ready to support USDA's efforts to safeguard animal health until the NWS fly can be pushed further south.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Chicken wing prices are lower this year despite high demand for Super Bowl LX, expected to reach 1.48 billion wings consumed.
- Wing popularity has surged in recent decades, becoming a cultural tradition like hot dogs on the 4th of July. 
- Wing production is limited by animal physiology, with only 2 flats and 2 drumettes per chicken.
- Wholesale wing prices are $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents at the start of 2026, but down from $1.99 last year, $2.65 in 2024, and $3.80 in 2022.
- Around 17.5 billion wings are expected to be produced this year, with 8.5% (1.48 billion) consumed during the Super Bowl.
- Expert David Anderson, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist, says wing demand is not expected to fade and has become part of Super Bowl culture.

Impacts for farmers:
- Stable or increasing demand for chicken wings, a valuable poultry cut.
- Potential profit opportunities around major events like the Super Bowl when demand peaks.
- Production limitations due to animal physiology may create supply challenges to meet surging demand.

No additional expert quotes or recommendations provided in the article.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle inventory has dipped again, with the total number of cattle and calves on farms and ranches as of January 1, 2026, at 86.2 million head, slightly below the previous year. The key figures from the USDA's National Agricultural Statistics Service report include:

- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (down from Jan. 1, 2025)
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year)
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from the prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

This suggests a slow start to herd rebuilding, with factors like moisture, forage, producer confidence, and willingness to hold back heifers influencing expansion. For cow-calf operators, the tight supplies and strong calf/bred female prices indicate a long road to rebuilding. Stocker and feedlot operators face elevated competition for feeder cattle. The data points to gradual, uneven expansion, driven more by regional conditions than headline prices.
